Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student and Early-Career Faculty Travel and Registration Grant for IEEE International Conference on Software Engineering 2018 (ICSE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests funds for to support travelers to the International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE 2018) to take place in Gothenburg, Sweden in May of 2018. ICSE is the flagship conference in the field. The grant will provide travel and registration support for students, researchers and early-career faculty to participate in three programs at the 2018 International Conference on Software Engineering?the Student Volunteers Program, the Doctoral Symposium, and the New Faculty Symposium.

The award will make possible the technical exchange of information and research collaborations, as well as advances in the field made possible by these interactions. The funded activity promotes education, training and mentoring of the participants. The international nature of this conference helps develop a globally-aware workforce of research and educators within the US and helps build the community of researchers in the field of Software Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broader impacts:

Participation in ICSE can have lasting impact on the research directions and careers of students and early-career faculty members in the field of software engineering. A total of 55 students applied for the NSF travel support and 11 were supported. 7 PhD students, 1 M.S., 1 undergraduate students, and 2 faculty members from 10 different schools were supported.  46% of survey respondents had not attended a prior ICSE indicating that the award gave new members a chance to attend the ICSE. At ICSE, they meet and interact with leading researchers, educators, and practitioners who are pioneering new directions in software engineering research and practice. The award helped students and faculty to share research ( 91% presented their research and 82% were interested in learning about latest research) or building a network (82% interested in networking). They gain an appreciation for the norms of the research community, an understanding of challenging research problems,and learn strengths and limitations of approaches for addressing these problems at the frontier of the field. They join a network of researchers with whom they can share ideas and collaborate to contribute to the body of knowledge of software engineering. Supporting meritorious students and faculty members from groups that are underrepresented in the field strengthens the field by introducing diversity of ideas and problem solving strategies. It also provides opportunity to many who would not have the means to attend ICSE. All award recipient found that they are interested in the meeting and willing to attend the future ICSEs. Given the pervasiveness of software in modern society and the need for a skilled software workforce for the U.S. to remain competitive in the world economy, the U.S.- based software engineering research community needs to draw from the full talent pool available. A travel award can help a student or faculty member from a group that is underrepresented in this community be successful, benefiting the community and providing necessary role models for others.


Intellectual merit:

ICSE provides an environment where ideas are created, exchanged, and synthesized as researchers, practitioners, and educators present and discuss the most recent innovations, trends, experiences, and challenges in the field of software engineering. Results presented at past ICSEs laid the foundation for work in areas ranging from software correctness and robustness, to software architecture and analysis, to the impact of software on society, and more. Similarly, leading-edge results reported at ICSE 2018 will lay the foundation for the future in areas known and unknown, as is vital for a world in which software has become ubiquitous.
